_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen pad on vessels/containers of flammables. Battery back up on process control computers. Fusible plugs on SO2 cylinders.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Automatic foam supplied to deluge system
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: LEL, SO2 and Ammonia detectors. Object video on SO2 storage area with motion detection alarming at EH&S.

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen pad on vessels/containers of flammables and battery back up on process control computers.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Automatic foam supplied to deluge system
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: LEL, chlorine, propylene and ammonia detectors
Two HCl monitors in tank dike, remote drainage to fire pit with sump LSH for monitoring liquid level
One HCl monitor and five chlorine monitors inside the process building

_prev_prog_3.PHA_OtherTechnique: Reactive chemical data review and Layers of protection analysis (LOPA)

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: LEL monitor for each V-2 pump
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Increased lower set point for pressure control in the Vinylidene Chloride tank from about 6 psig to 10 psig

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Video cameras, LELs, GC's and chloralerts

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  Appropriate controls are implemented to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If a release were to occur, highly trained emergency response personnel are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.  The facility also coordinates with the City of Midland Fire Department and Midland LEPC which can provide additional emergency response expertise.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations primary activity is chemical manufacturing, including agricultural and specialty chemicals.  There are three (3) covered processes, eight (8) programs and eight (8) regulated substances present at the stationary source.  

The regulated substances are listed below.  
Regulated Substances:

Ammonia (anhydrous)
Chlorine
Crotonaldehyde [2-butenal]
Dimethylamine
Phosphorus oxychloride
Phosphorus trichloride
Sulfur dioxide
Vinylidene chloride

Worst and Alternative Case Scenario Selection

There was one (1) worst case toxic and one (1) worst case flammable scenario reported in this submittal. There are seven (7) total alternate cases, one of which is a flammable case.  Most of the toxic alternate cases were reported due to that being the only alternate case for the chemical.  No toxic alternate cases for chlorine impacted a population, so the scenario reported for chlorine was the only alternate case that reached an endpoint off-site. The flammable alternate case was chosen due to it being the closest scenario to affect a population based on the location in the plant.  It has the closest scenario with an endpoint to an off-site location. EPA RMP*Comp and MARPLOT were used to evaluate the worst and alternate case scenarios. 

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Dow

esponse to all Dow Agrosciences, LLC plants and maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan documents all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, and post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The plan is updated as necessary to reflect any pertinent changes within the processes at the facility that would require a modified emergency response.

The facility works with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) of Midland County with which the facility emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

Emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced in order to ensure that it is functioning properly at all times.  

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of the accidental release prevention program.  Development of Environmental Health and Safety Work Processes, a concentrated Behavior Based Safety effort, and company-wide Environmental Health & Safety goals are some of the major steps taken to improve safety at the Source.  The Michigan Operations Site also works with the Department of Homeland Security to ensure full compliance with the Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.

AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable company and governing agency requirements at the time of construction.  Modifications to existing structures are also done in compliance with applicable company standards and governing agency requirements.  Several processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 19 CFR 1910.119.  The facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations.

Process Safety Information

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations maintains detailed records of safety information that, among other things, describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment design associated with all covered processes.  Numerous types of information are available to supplement safety information, including Safety Data Sheets for materials used on site, equipment and engineering design specifications and applicable reactive chemicals testing.

Process Hazard Analysis

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  Findings related to the hazard analyses are addressed in a timely manner.
Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered processes, Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is

readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel receive specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and receive training on the modification.

Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications of existing processes are conducted as a regular practice at Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment and operating & maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule and other applicable regulatory requirements are being followed and have bee

n implemented properly. Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the root causes leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring.  

Employee Participation

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations has a written employee participation plan which operates on the premise that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues, to attend applicable reviews, and to recommend improvements.  Improvements are solicited and implemented as appropriate.  In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. 

Contractors

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  The facility has a strict program for informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes, as well as the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.  Contractors are also required to inform the facility of any hazards they may introduce or encounter while at the site.

Five-year Accident History

Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations had no reportable accidents involving RMP chemicals that occurred at this facility within the past five years.

Emergency Response Plan

Dow Chemical ES&S provides emergency r

2019 General Executive Summary for Dow AgroSciences, LLC Midland Operations 

Revisions to the Plan:

Revisions to the March 29th, 2019 plan are being submitted on October 30th, 2019 for the following reasons:

Ownership Transfer of Assets at Chemical Distribution from Dow Agrosciences, LLC to DDP Specialty Electronic Materials US, Inc.:
Ownership of the Anhydrous HCl Low Purity (Rail Cars), Anhydrous HCl High Purity (Tube Trailers) and Propylene Oxide assets will be transferred to DDP Specialty Electronic Materials US, Inc. on November 1st, 2019.  DDP Specialty Electronic Materials US, Inc.  will also be taking operational control of Anhydrous HCl High Purity and Propylene Oxide at the same time. Operational control of the Anhydrous HCl Low Purity asset is scheduled to be transferred in early 2020. This submittal removes all processes, programs, covered chemicals and scenarios that will not belong to Dow Agrosciences, LLC going forward. 

Removal of Regulated Substances:
Removed Anhydrous HCl from Building 1 since the plant has blown out the pipeline within their block limits and installed a blind flange to the site header on May 13th, 2019. They are no longer using anhydrous HCl at their facility. 

Non-Applicability for Anhydrous HCl due to Removal of Interconnectivity:
Changed the 680 and 1028 plants to non-applicable for Anhydrous HCl, since they have less than the applicable threshold limit within their block.  These plants were only applicable for Anhydrous HCl before due to interconnectivity with the site header which was owned by Dow Agrosciences, LLC. Now that the site header and distribution asset for Anhydrous HCl is owned by DDP Specialty Electronic Materials US, Inc., the interconnectivity definition doesn't apply.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
